AIRCZ Type: AIRPORTDescription: Heathrow Planning Consultation Zone: All buildings, structures, erections and works exceeding 90 metres in height (295.3 feet)Contact: The Safeguarding Department, Heathrow Airport Limited, c/o Planning Services, First Point, Buckingham Gate, Gatwick Airport, West Sussex, RH6 0NT

application_details.scheme_name: First And Second Floors, 12 Fife Road

description: Change of use of first and second floors from class B1a offices to four class C3 residential flats (1x1 bed and 3x2 bed), associated external alterations to rear together with the provision of bin and bike stores and access gate to side.
decision_conditions: Development  shall  be  carried  out  in  accordance  with  the  materials  specified  on  the approved plans and on the application form unless otherwise agreed in writing by the Local Planning Authority.Reason: To ensure a satisfactory appearance on completion of the development in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.
The development hereby permitted shall begin before the expiration of three years from the date of this permission.Reason: This is required by Section 91 of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990.

Notwithstanding the details shown on drawing 03E (Proposed Floor Plans) the accommodation hereby permitted shall not be occupied until cycle parking provision  for a total of 7 spaces has been provided on site, in accordance with details which have been approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority. The cycle storage facilities shall thereafter be kept free of obstruction and available for the parking of cycles only.Reason: To ensure the provision of adequate cycling facilities in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012

No building or use hereby permitted shall be occupied or the use commenced until the refuse store, and area/facilities allocated for storing of recyclable materials, as shown on approved plan no. 05E have been completed in accordance with the approved plans. The developer and/or their successors in title shall take all reasonable steps to ensure that all refuse and recyclable materials associated with the development shall either be stored within this dedicated store/area as shown on the approved plans, or internally within the building(s) that form part of the application site, and that no refuse or recycling material shall be stored or placed for collection on the public highway or pavement, except on the day of collection.Reason: To ensure the provision of refuse facilities to the satisfaction of the Council in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Prior to commencement of the use hereby approved evidence must be submitted to the Council confirming that the development hereby permitted has achieved no less than the C02 reductions (ENE1), internal water usage (WAT1) standards equivalent to Code for Sustainable Homes Level 4.  Evidence requirements are detailed in the "Schedule of Evidence Required for Post Construction Stage from ENE1 and WAT1 of the Code for Sustainable Homes Guide.  Evidence to demonstrate a 19% reduction compared to 2013 Part L regulations and internal water usage rates of 105L/day.Reason: In the interests of Sustainability and Energy Conservation in accordance with Policies 5.2 (Minimising Carbon Dioxide Emissions) and 5.3 (Sustainable Design & Construction) of the London Plan (July 2011) and Policy DM1 (Sustainable Design and Construction Standards) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

No development shall take place including any works of demolition until a construction logistics plan has been submitted to and been approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority.  The approved plan/statement shall be adhered to throughout the construction period. The statement shall provide for:(a) Provision for loading/unloading materials.(b) Storage of plant, materials and operatives vehicles.(c) Temporary site access.(d) Signing system for works traffic.(e) Measures for the laying of dust, suppression of noise and abatement of other nuisance arising from development works.(f) Location of all ancillary site buildings.(g) Measures to protect any tree, shrubbery and other landscape features to be retained on the site during the course of development.(h) Means of enclosure of the site.(i) Wheel washing equipment.(j) The parking of vehicles of the site operatives and visitors(k) The erection and maintenance of security hoarding.Reason: These details are required prior to commencement of development because  the relevant works would take place at the beginning of the construction phase and in order to safeguard the amenities of the surrounding residential occupiers and to safeguard highway safety and the free flow of traffic in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

The development shall be completed in accordance with the following details which shall have been submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority, prior to occupation of the development and before commencement of the relevant part of the development(a) details of access gate, including materials.(b) details of covered cycle store.(c) details of covered refuse and recycling storage enclosure(d) details of recessed balconies, including materialsThe development shall be implemented in accordance with the approved details prior to occupation of the flats hereby approved and maintained thereafter.Reason: To ensure a satisfactory appearance on completion of the development in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

The site and building works required to implement the development shall be only carried out between the hours of 08.00 and 18.00 Mondays to Fridays and between 08.00 and 13.00 on Saturdays and not at all on Bank Holidays and Sundays.Reason:  To safeguard the amenities of the adjoining residential occupiers in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

The site comprises a two-storey detached dwelling located on the southside of Woodside Road, which is a well-established residential area. The properties are characterised by a narrow width and are separated by a passageway to the side of each property. There are examples of single storey rear extensions at neighbouring properties, though not any examples of first floor additions. The property is not listed, nor is it within a conservation area though it is within a Local Area of Special Character. The property is also within flood zone 2, as defined by the Environment Agency, and so is at a medium risk of flooding. Ground levels appear consistent with the neighbouring properties.8 neighbouring properties were notified of the application and three letters of objection were received following the consultation period. The planning issues raised are:- Excessive height or bulk- Loss of light/sunlight- Unacceptable or incompatible use- Car parking issues- Loss of trees- Noise- PrivacyThe key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development;- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings; - The impact of the development on the risk of flooding in and around the site; and- Other issues raised by the consultation responses. When read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. The proposal will involve the demolition of a single storey rear extension at the rear of the property. It is not considered that it possesses any significant architectural merit and so there is no objection to its loss. The proposal will involve the erection of a part-two, part-single storey extension. The proposed ground floor aspect will project 4.5m from the rear of the property, a net increase of 2.5m from the original footprint of the property, and a 2m projection at first floor level. The size of the resultant extension would be in keeping with the scale of the original property. Due to the built up nature of the area, the proposal would not be readily visible from any public viewpoint, though the use of appropriate materials would ensure that there is no adverse impact upon the character and appearance of the area. Policy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.The proposal would increase the footprint of the property and therefore reduce the amount of amenity space available. However, given the depth of the rear garden, adequate space would be retained for residents to enjoy and undertake their day-to-day activities. Due to the passageways either side of the property, the extension would be set in from each of the side boundaries which will ensure that there is no dominating impact from the extension. Due to the orientation of the properties, there may be some loss of sunlight to the neighbour at no. 23, however any loss would be for a short period of time first thing in the morning. The ground floor aspect of the extension would have a flat roof that could be accessed from first floor and used as an outdoor seating area/balcony. A condition can be imposed to prevent such use to ensure that neighbouring properties do not suffer from increased noise disturbance or overlooking. Consequently, it is considered that acceptable levels of residential amenity would be maintained for both occupants of the property and their neighbours. The application site falls within Flood Risk Zone 2. Consequently the Flood Risk Assessment: Standing Advice issued by the Environment Agency and DEFRA, 2012 must be applied. For minor extensions such as this it is essential that the proposed floor level is no lower than existing in order to mitigate future flood risk impacts. Concern has been raised that the increased size of the property would result in further demand for on-street parking. The property would remain as one single dwelling and the extension is modest in size so it would not result in undue pressure for on street parking space. There are also no trees of high amenity value that would be affected by the proposal.It is considered that the proposed extension would be in scale and character with the host property and would not have an adverse impact on the character and appearance of the area. Residential amenity would not be compromised and there are no concerns that the proposal would increase the risk of flooding in and around the site. In conclusion, the proposed development would be in general accordance with the National Planning Policy Framework (2019), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan, Policies of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).

The proposed erection of hip to gable and rear dormer roof extensions and installation of 2no. rooflights to front roofslope falls within the parameters of permitted development as set out under Schedule 2, Part 1, Class B & Class C of the Town and Country Planning (General Permitted Development) (England) Order 2015 (as amended).

The site comprises a semi-detached dwelling.Five neighbouring properties have been notified and no representations have been received.The key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development; - The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings; and,- Car and cycle parking.When read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer Comment: Officers note similar permissions have been granted at No. 51 & No. 55 Cambridge Avenue. Officers acknowledge that the lack of set back from the front elevation is not fully compliant with policy 36 of the Residential Design SPD but consider it acceptable due to the prevailing pattern of development in the street, where numerous side extensions have not been set back. A characteristic gap between properties has been maintained between No. 51 and No. 53 Cambridge Avenue.  The proposed development is considered to be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design. It is considered that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development.Policy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment:  It is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.Policy DM9 of the Council's LDF Core Strategy (2012) states that new development must comply with local car parking standards in order that it does not contribute to congestion or compromise highway safety.  Policy DM10 supports this stance. Officer Comment: Despite the loss of the existing garage, it is considered that the hardstanding to the front of the dwelling remains of an adequate size to accommodate 1 off street car parking space, therefore the proposal would comply with the standards set out in Policy T6.1 and Table 10.1 of the London Plan 2021 and Policy DM9 and DM10 of the Core Strategy 2012.Policy T5 of the London Plan 2021 states that developments should provide cycle parking at least in accordance with the minimum standards set out in Table 10.2 and Figure 10.3. Despite the loss of the garage and potential cycle storage therein, the application property and garden is of an adequate size to accommodate dedicated and secure cycle storage and access from the front of the property to the rear would be retained.  Therefore, the proposal is considered to achieve general compliance with Policy T5.In conclusion, the proposed development would be in general accordance with the National Planning Policy Framework (2019), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan 2021, Policies of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).

The site comprises a semi-deatched dwelling.The key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development; and,- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of and and buildings.When read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer Comment: The proposed development is considered unacceptable in terms of scale, siting and design at the side at first floor. It is considered that the proposed first floor side extension would be an incongruous addition to the host property. It is considered its proportions would appear 'squat' and 'stark' and would jar with the overall character and appearance of the host property and unbalance the pair of semi-detached properties the host property forms part of and as a result would be visually intrusive in the streetscene.  It is considered that there would be an unacceptable adverse impact on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposals.Policy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment:  It is considered that the proposed development would not have an unacceptable adverse impact upon the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance/loss of light/loss of privacy (delete as appropriate).In conclusion, the proposal is considered to be contrary to policies CS8 and DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

In accordance with the requirements of Local Government Act 1972 The Plans / Drawings / Documents submitted with the application were available on the Council's website during the assessment of the application.https://www.kingston.gov.uk/info/200155/planning_applications_and_permissions/263/find_a_planning_application_or_appeal

Please be advised that the revised elevations submitted do not scale correctly at 1:100 as stated. 	As well as the drawings  (both are titled A104 - Guest House Elevations) should be clearly titled as "existing" and "propose"
Please provide the address of the applicant in the section 2 of application form.
Please amend and resubmit drawing number RF.00 Proposed Roof Details (2 drawings titled the same), however they differ slightly. Please confirm/resubmit the correct drawing.

Please submit a copy of an Ordnance Survey based site location plan scaled 1:1250 with the application site outlined in red and adjoining land owned by applicant in blue, showing at least two road frontages and a North point.The submitted location plan is incorrectly labelled as 161 Gilders Road.

Please revise and provide a copy of block plan scaled 1:500 showing adjoining properties to the side and rear and those opposite in full outline.  The proposed works should be (hatched or shaded) in relation to the existing dwelling, site boundaries and any outbuildings on site.
